lines.text:
[looking at a carving]
What does that mean?
Gnothe seauthon. Know yourself. The watchword of Apollo.
The god of prophecy?
Among other things...
[Later at the close of the scene]

[contemplating the temple she has visited]
Know yourself. That's quite a watchword. Gnothe seauthon.
You're most retentive.
Give me a good line and I can remember it.
Did you not hear Miss Bridges ask you to go?
Who are you?
It doesn't matter who I am. It only matters that Miss Bridges wishes you to leave her house, and you are, therefore, leaving it.
Yes, well, you're very active for your age!
Since you cannot conceivably know what my age is, your most flattering compliment must be based on a somewhat conjectural premise.

[laughs]
You've done it again. Now that's three times you've made me laugh. And only this morning I thought I'd never laugh again. I suppose it's your being a schoolmaster.

[insulted]
I fail to see what is so laughable about that.
Well, no, it's not laughable. One doesn't laugh at people only because they're funny. Not some people. C'mon... there's so much to see before the sun goes down on us...
I've met you somewhere before. I certainly remember that voice.
Now here are your stick and hat, and that, as you plainly know, is the front door.
Katie, you...?
Straight ahead, please.
That voice. There's something about it. I don't know who you are, but I can guess what you are. You're a school teacher, aren't you?
Correct.
I bet you give your boys hell.
Only the bad ones.
An ancient ruin did you say, my dear?

[upon seeing Katie]
This isn't a joke, is it?
Chippings lost all sense of proportion.
Some people might think he'd found it.
No, the allusion was to the stage which used to be my profession.
Indeed.
You're an actress, Mrs. Chipping?
Well, not even my best friends would call me that.

[snidely]
Aw, and what would they call you?
A soubrette. That's the girl in musical comedy who sings the big number and, in the end, loses the man.
[Chuckles]
In real life, they nearly always end up the wives of earls. I nearly did. But luckily... I met Chips.
The headmaster's a darling. His wife's a bitch.
That's not a word we use here.
You should I think.
Oh, but I adore English public schools! I simply worship them all! Even that idiotic Westchester... where you can't ask a boy out to tea without everyone asking the most extraordinary questions.
Ursula, darling, you must see the bell tower. And here's your guide (pointing to Herr Staefel).
The bell tower? (realizing Katie's unspoken intention) Oh, yes, of course... the bell tower! (Laughs) Later...
I hope you like early English perpendicular.
Darling, I revel in early English perpendicular!

[to his students]
There was a boy who, when asked to translate into Latin Tennyson's beautiful lines "Break, break, break on Thy cold grey stones, O Sea," came up with "O fluctus, fluctus, rumpety-rumpety jam!" (laughter from the class) He's now a bishop. (More laughter)
You are William C. Belfridge's ward. Miss Katherine Bridges.
Now that's wrong, too. It's not my real name. My real name is... now you won't laugh, will you? It's Brisket.
Charmingly Anglo-Saxon.

[after Miss Honeybun interrupts them]
Oh, I'm extremely sorry, I was kissing my wife.
Why?
I don't know, really. It somehow seemed a good idea at the time.
Is my wife here?
Wife? Which wife, darling?
She was called Katherine Bridges.
Katie? Of course she's here! Did you say 'wife,' darling?
Yes.
Well, that would make you her husband, wouldn't it?
Yes, it would.
Then she's not here, darling. She's nowhere near the place.
Of course, you two are married or something, aren't you?
Married, madam, and quite definitely not something.
I adore this man. When you're finished with him, Katie, lend him to me.
I don't think I do know you.
You must be mad. What's your name?
Arthur Chipping.
That's right. You take to drink.
I do not take to drink, madam. Excuse me.
By the way, how do you know she isn't here?
She?
The girl the Evening News said you were going to marry?
Oh, yes. I saw that. Me and Penelope Fitzdouglas. Isn't it ridiculous?
Sidesplitting.
Sorry, am I going too fast for you?

My dear young lady, I could easily go just as fast as you if I cared to risk a broken ankle and be carried back on a stretcher. It's extremely foolish to leap around in a ruined circus like a mountain goat. Especially in those shoes. These stones are treacherous.
I'm going to ask Apollo a question.
You mustn't ask a personal question, well, not a specific one like uh...
Like "Will Bill Calbury come back to me?" No (sighs), I won't bore Apollo with that, I promise you.
Chippings' waiting for his wife, I think.

[skeptical]
His wife?
Flabbergasting. Who on earth?
Who on earth indeed?
[hoots]
It's what we've all been asking ourselves ever since we heard the news.
It's apparently someone he met on one of his excursions to the ancient ruins of Pompeii.
Somewhat of an ancient ruin herself, no doubt.
[chuckles]
I'm so terribly sorry about being late. Chips says it's almost as bad as being off your number.
I'm afraid I don't quite understand that allusion, Mrs. Chippings.
Oh, Mrs. Chippings! I just love when I'm called that.
And you are that, yes?
Oh, yes! Well and truly! Well, unless Chips is a bigamist which I rather suspect. How else could he have escaped... until now?
We must go in, dear. The headmaster always goes in last, and the boys always receive him standing and in silence.
Sounds like a dream entrance.

[to his students]
The Lex Canuleia is not, as Cawley Minor seems to think, a law regulating canals, but a law that permitted Roman patricians to marry plebeians. An easy way to remember it is to imagine a Miss Plebeian wishing to marry a Mr. Patrician, and Mr. Patrician saying he can't. She could then reply "Oh yes, you can, you liar."
I refuse utterly to become the secret lover of a well-known actress.
Who said lover?
Well, friend, I would like to be.
Who said friend?
What is there between lover and friend?
Husband.
